bestBHT.bht: This promise of peace is not just an ordinary peace, but the highest and most glorious sense of peace. It is a crown of glory that never fades away and brings honor beyond that of earthly rulers. This peace encompasses not only tranquility but also abundance and prosperity. It is available to both Jews and Gentiles, with the Jews having the privilege of being first in salvation if they are obedient to the truth. It is a peace that surpasses understanding, granting deliverance from tribulation and anguish, and serving as a testament of divine approval.

Henry Alford: 10. peace] Here in its highest and most glorious sense: see ch. 6, x. 15; John xiv. 27.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: perdition if unfaithful; but if obedient to the truth, first in
Philip Schaff: 'Peace' is here used in its fullest sense...
...includes 'peace, plenty, and prosperity,' but with more of a temporal reference than...
Comp. chap. Romans 8:6, and similar passages.
John Gill: Which is a 'crown of glory that fadeth not away'" (1 Peter 5:4)
An honour exceeding that of the greatest potentates upon earth
A peace that passes all understanding
John Wesley: But glory — Just opposite to "wrath," from the divine approbation.
Honour — Opposite to "indignation," by the divine appointment; and peace now and for ever, opposed to tribulation and anguish.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse speaks of the promise of peace, which is described as the highest and most glorious sense of peace and includes peace, plenty, and prosperity. This peace is offered to both Jews and Gentiles, with the Jews being the first in terms of potential perdition if unfaithful, but also the first in salvation if obedient to the truth. This peace is not just a temporal reference, but a peace that surpasses understanding and is a crown of glory that never fades away. It is an honor that exceeds that of the greatest rulers on earth and is a testament to divine approval. It is a peace that brings ultimate peace and freedom from tribulation and anguish.

This passage speaks of the promise of the highest and most glorious sense of peace, which is a crown of glory that never fades away. It is an honor that exceeds that of worldly rulers and brings peace, plenty, and prosperity. This peace is available to both Jews and Gentiles, with the Jews having the privilege of being the first in salvation if they are obedient to the truth. It is a peace that surpasses understanding, offering freedom from tribulation and anguish, and is a testament to divine approval.

The promise of peace described in this verse is the highest and most glorious sense of peace. It is a crown of glory that never fades away, an honor surpassing that of worldly rulers. The peace includes abundance and prosperity. Both Jews and Gentiles can partake in this peace, with the Jews having the opportunity of being the first in salvation if they are obedient to the truth. This peace surpasses understanding, offering liberation from tribulation and anguish and serving as a testament to divine approval.

This promise of peace goes beyond the ordinary meaning of the word. It is the highest and most glorious sense of peace, a crown of glory that never fades away. This peace brings honor, exceeding that of even the greatest earthly rulers. It is a peace that encompasses not just tranquility but also abundance and prosperity. This promise is offered to both Jews and Gentiles, with the Jews having the privilege of being first in salvation if they are obedient to the truth. It is a peace that surpasses understanding, providing deliverance from tribulation and anguish, and a sign of divine approval.

This promise of peace is not just an ordinary peace, but the highest and most glorious sense of peace. It is a crown of glory that never fades away and brings honor beyond that of earthly rulers. This peace encompasses not only tranquility but also abundance and prosperity. It is available to both Jews and Gentiles, with the Jews having the privilege of being first in salvation if they are obedient to the truth. It is a peace that surpasses understanding, granting deliverance from tribulation and anguish, and serving as a testament of divine approval.
